thread.title: iiNet execs collect $25m for exit
thread.title_full: iiNet execs collect $25m for exit | Business Spectator

author: Mitchell Bingemann - The Australian
title: iiNet execs collect $25m for exit
text:
Internet provider iiNet’s top three executives are set to reap a combined $25 million worth of ­bonuses as the company’s sale to TPG Telecom is finalised and buyout cheques are mailed to shareholders.
The company’s recently departed chief executive David Buckingham will receive the largest payment among his peers, netting close to $9m in combined long-term incentive bonuses and termination payments.
Of that bonanza, $7m will come through the sale of about a million shares that were awarded to him over the last three years as part of his long-term incentive bonus, while another payment of about $1.8m — reflecting his salary from his last year of full employment — will be paid for the early termination of his contract.
Mr Buckingham was made redundant just nine days after the $1.56 billion acquisition of iiNet by TPG Telecom was approved by the courts. The company’s chief business officer, Greg Bader, will receive a cheque for about $8.7m with the vesting of shares obtained through his long-term incentives, while the company’s chief operating officer, Maryna Fewster, will receive about $8m from the same bonus program.
TPG’s billionaire boss David Teoh has wasted no time in purging executives from iiNet since taking full control of the company last month. Mr Buckingham was the first to go while iiNet’s long-serving head of NBN strategy and product, Rachel McIntyre, left the company last week. There are rumours circulating that other high-ranking executives in the company will also soon depart.
The exit of Mr Buckingham — who was also overseeing the duties of chief financial officer — has created a power vacuum at the head of iiNet.
Multiple sources close to iiNet have claimed that Mr Teoh’s son and current TPG non-executive board member, Shane Teoh, has been appointed as the company’s new CFO.
Shane Teoh, 30, has been a TPG board member since 2012. He holds a bachelor of commerce and a bachelor of law from the University of NSW and is the managing director of accounting and taxation software developer Total Forms.
But TPG chief financial officer Stephen Banfield emphatically denied that Mr Teoh, or any other candidate, had been appointed as iiNet’s new CEO. “No, that’s not correct,” he told The Australian .
The company’s broader shareholder base will also receive ­proceeds from the $1.56bn sale to TPG, albeit in much smaller packets when they are paid out today.
TPG’s takeover will see the bulk of iiNet’s shareholders receive a cash payment of $9.55 a share, consisting of $8.80 for the scrip and a 75c dividend. Shareholders who elected to receive TPG scrip will pick up 0.5533 TPG shares for each iiNet share they own and $3.82 in cash.
The total cash consideration for the sale of shares in the possession of iiNet’s three top executives came in at less than $9.55 a share each as they were awarded their performance rights in three tranches over three years. The trio also received performance rights under another long-term incentive plan that has since completed.
The executives landed their mammoth payday after successfully hitting the targets of their long-term incentive plans, which required that they deliver consistent and total shareholder returns of more than 20 per cent over the last three years.
iiNet chairman Michael Smith, who enthusiastically approved the TPG deal, is also set for a lucrative payday and will receive close to $2.6m for his 270,000 shares.
But the largest single payout will go to NBN Co board director and internet entrepreneur Simon Hackett whose three million iiNet shares will net him $28.65m. He accumulated his stake when he sold his business Internode to iiNet in 2011 for $105m. His sale to iiNet also gave him a 7.5 per cent stake in the company but that has been progressively sold down in the past five years to about 2 per cent prior to TPG’s purchase.
This article first appeared in The Australian Business Review
